Selectively converting glucose to fructose using immobilized tertiary amines Nitish Deshpande Lagnajit Pattanaik Mariah R. Whitaker Chi-Ta Yang Li-Chiang Lin Nicholas A. Brunelli ⁎ The Ohio State University, William G. Lowrie Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, 151 W. Woodruff Ave., Columbus, OH 43210, United States The Ohio State University William G. Lowrie Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering 151 W. Woodruff Ave. Columbus OH 43210 United States ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Glucose isomerization to fructose is an important step in upgrading biomass to higher valued products. Tertiary amines can be highly selective catalysts for this reaction. In this work, tertiary amine analogues were functionalized on a mesoporous silica support to create heterogeneous catalytic materials. Experiments with homogeneous catalysts and silica revealed that silanols reduced the catalytic activity. Through using different strategies to limit amine-silanol interactions, it is determined that tuning parameters such as amine loading and alkyl linker length of the amine tether increases the fructose yield by a factor of four. Among the catalysts tested, the one found to be the best for glucose isomerization has a high amine loading (∼0.95mmolg−1) with a methyl linker. Catalyst reuse tests demonstrated that organosilane leaching reduced amine content, but the immobilized amines with the methyl linker retained greater catalytic activity than amines with propyl linkers. Keywords Biomass Glucose isomerization Linker length Aminosilica materials 1 Introduction Catalytic material design is critical for enhancing catalyst activity and selectivity. Indeed, the precisely designed catalyst can enhance activity by an order of magnitude [1,2] and improve catalytic selectivity [3]. While many design discoveries have been made for homogeneous catalysts, it is desirable to translate these discoveries to heterogeneous catalytic materials since these can be more easily separated from the reaction mixture to yield the desired product, making the process more environmentally friendly. Translating these discoveries to heterogeneous catalytic materials presents a considerable challenge since heterogeneous catalytic materials often are non-uniform and present other complications. Therefore, additional research is necessary to investigate these design challenges and identify methods to ensure high catalytic activity and selectivity. Identifying design features that can increase catalytic activity and selectivity is particularly important for biomass related reactions such as the isomerization of glucose to fructose. Interest in this reaction has greatly expanded with the discovery that the Lewis acidic catalyst Sn-BEA can selectively convert glucose to fructose [4]. The unprecedented results for Sn-BEA have produced numerous investigations that create a more detailed understanding of the catalytic process, but the performance remains limited for Sn-BEA since it has been demonstrated that the catalyst deactivates [5] presumably through leaching of Sn active sites from the catalyst [6]. Therefore, alternative catalysts have been investigated, including recent work examining base catalyzed reactions [7–9]. The base catalyzed method was thought to be poorly selective since inorganic bases tended to give low yields and selectivities [10–13]. However, recent work with organic bases such as triethylamine demonstrates that catalytic materials using base can offer a viable route for fructose production [7]. The most selective organic base catalyst was a tertiary amine. The current understanding is that tertiary amines serve to create a hydroxide ion that is thought to be responsible for the catalytic activity. These homogeneous catalytic results provide a basis for creating heterogeneous catalytic materials that can be separated from the reaction mixture, facilitating product purification. Recent work on catalyst immobilization have targeted polymers [14] and magnetic nanoparticles [15], finding good yields from the heterogeneous catalysts. Magnetic nanoparticles are intriguing because of the facile separation process, but these tend to be utilized for specialty applications rather than bulk chemical processing because of current costs. Organic polymers and mesoporous silicas often provide complementary strategies for catalyst immobilization. Polymers can have higher loadings, but can have complex solvent and temperature dependent phase behavior that introduce mass-transfer limitations to the system and limit the accessibility of catalytic sites. Mesoporous silica has a rigid backbone that creates uniform pores that facilitate access to the catalytic sites. The improved mass transfer comes with the disadvantage that the organosilanes can leach, which can be catalyzed by basic organosilanes [16]. While typical organosilanes have a propyl linker and attach to the silica surface on average via a bipodal manner (two attachment points) [17], recent work investigating the effect of alkyl linker length on reaction rates found that an aminosilane containing a methyl linker between the nitrogen and silicon atom was found to attach via a tripodal attachment [18]. The increased number of attachment points would potentially increase the stability. Simultaneously, a methyl linker may limit the ability of the amine to catalyze the siloxy bond cleavage, limiting the overall amount of leaching. Herein is described work to investigate a series of mesoporous silica catalytic materials containing tertiary amines for the isomerization of glucose to fructose (Fig. 1 ). Investigations focused on the effect of the loading and the alkyl linker length of the organosilane on catalytic performance. The materials are also investigated in catalytic recycle experiments to understand the nature of deactivation. Overall, the work demonstrates the importance of catalytic material design to increase catalyst performance. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were used as received with no further purification with the exception of toluene. Toluene (ACS grade, Macron Fine Chemicals) was dried using an MB-SPS DriSolv system (MBraun Inc.). The following chemicals were used tetraethylorthosilicate (98%, Acros Organics), hydrochloric acid (36.5–38.0% by wt., reagent grade, J. T. Baker), poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) PEG-PPG-PEG, Pluronic® P-123 (Sigma-Aldrich), hexamethyldisilazane (>99%, Sigma-Aldrich), (N,N-diethylaminomethyl) triethoxysilane (Gelest), (N,N-diethyl-3-aminopropyl) trimethoxysilane (Gelest), hexanes (ACS grade, Macron Fine Chemicals), dextrose (USP grade, Fisher), D-(+)-mannose (99%, Alfa Aesar), D-fructose (99%, Alfa Aesar), D-mannitol (USP grade, Amresco), dimethylsulfoxide (>99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich), acetonitrile (>99.9%, VWR Analytical), tetrahydrofuran (>99.9%, Fisher Scientific, HPLC grade), and reagent alcohol (BDH VWR Analytical). De-Ionized (DI) water was obtained from a house supply that produces Milli-Q quality water. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis Pure silica SBA-15 was synthesized using procedures reported in literature [19,20]. Organosilanes with tertiary amine functionality were immobilized onto this SBA-15 using methods reported in literature [19]. The organosilanes that were separately grafted on silica surface were (N,N-diethyl-3-aminopropyl) trimethoxysilane (C3) and (N,N-diethylaminomethyl) triethoxy silane (C1). The convention used for naming the materials involved the organosilane linker length (C1 vs. C3) and the actual loading. For a material functionalized with C3 and an actual loading of 0.52mmolg−1, the material was labeled SBA-C3-0.52. Materials capped with hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS) were labeled according to its tertiary amine type and loading with “-HMDS” as a suffix. 2.3 Material characterization The materials were characterized using a battery of standard techniques, including nitrogen physisorption, thermo-gravimetric analysis with differential scanning calorimetry (TGA-DSC), elemental (CHN) analysis, and 29Si CP/MAS NMR. The textural properties of the materials were analyzed using Micromeritics 3Flex surface characterization analyzer. All samples display type (IV) adsorption-desorption isotherms, consistent with isotherm behavior for mesoporous materials like SBA-15. The surface area and pore volume were calculated using the BET method while the pore size was determined using the BdB-FHH method [21]. Data for all materials is presented on a per gram of silica basis that was determined through accounting for organic content from TGA. TGA-DSC were performed using STA 449 F5 Jupiter® (NETZSCH instruments). Analysis was performed under flowing air (20mL/min) and nitrogen (20mL/min) at a ramp rate of 10°C/min from 30°C to 900°C followed by a 5min hold at 900°C. Elemental analysis was performed by Atlantic Microlab, Inc. (Norcross, GA) on all the samples to determine the weight percentages of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen in the functionalized samples. The weight percentage of nitrogen was used to calculate the loading of organosilane functionalized onto the catalysts. Solid-state 29Si CP/MAS NMR experiments were performed using Bruker DSX 300MHz spectrometer operating at 59.6MHz for 29Si. (3-(trimethylsilyl)-1-propanesulfonic acid sodium salt) is used as the chemical shift reference (0ppm). Experimental parameters included magic angle spinning at 5kHz, a cross-polarization time of 5ms, relaxation delay of 2s, and 1H decoupling at ∼90kHz. 2.4 Catalytic testing - Kinetic evaluation Isomerization reactions were carried out in 15mL glass pressure tubes equipped with magnetic Teflon stir bars (VWR). These pressure tubes were heated in a silicone oil bath using a digital temperature-controlled stirring hot plate (Heidolph). A bulk reaction solution consisting of 4.0g dextrose and 36.0g DI water was prepared. Twograms of this solution were combined with an amount of the catalyst to achieve an equivalent amount of amine loading of 10mol%. The pressure tube was sealed using a Teflon cap equipped with a back-sealing O-ring and placed in a pre-heated (100°C) oil bath for fixed intervals of time. The reaction was quenched by placing the reactor in an ice bath for 15min. Weighing the pressure tubes before and after the reaction showed no loss of its contents. The reaction mixture was diluted with 4g of 0.3Md-mannitol solution (internal standard for HPLC measurements). The pressure tube was closed and shaken vigorously before taking a 1.8mL sample using disposable syringes. The sample was then filtered using a 0.22μm nylon ( ∅ =13mm) syringe filter and analyzed using High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) from Waters (Acquity) equipped with a refractive index (RI) detector. Glucose, fructose, and mannitol concentrations were monitored using Waters Sugar Pak-1 column equipped with a pre-column filter. DI water was used as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 0.20mL/min and a column temperature of 70°C. Using the Weisz-Prater criteria and varying the stirring speed to examine mass transfer limitations at the reaction conditions, it can be concluded that mass transfer effects did not affect the results (Tables S8 and S9). For reactions under nitrogen, a similar procedure was followed, except the reaction was performed in a Schlenk tube and the reaction mixture was degassed using freeze (liquid nitrogen)-thaw cycles (4 times). To understand how the solution pH changed during the reaction, pH measurements were made as described in the supplementary information. 2.5 Catalyst reuse testing The ability to reuse the catalyst was evaluated by testing the catalyst in a series of glucose isomerization reactions. Since catalytic testing was evaluated using single data points, the first reaction was scaled by a factor of five to enable recovery of sufficient material to perform recycle reactions. The first catalytic test was performed using a single neck 25mL round bottom flask equipped with a condenser and sealed using a septum. After 5h, the reaction was quenched and the mixture analyzed for glucose conversion and fructose selectivity as described above. The remaining reaction mixture, now also consisting of the external standard solution (d-mannitol in DI water), was filtered using a small 2-piece filtration set-up. The filtered catalyst was washed with 50mL DI water and left to dry overnight at room temperature followed by oven-drying (80°C) overnight. The material was characterized after drying using nitrogen physisorption and TGA to identify any change in porosity and adsorption of species from the reaction mixture onto the catalyst. The remaining catalyst was used to obtain two data points for the conversion at different times to check for any changes in the initial reaction rates after using the catalyst once. The recycle tests were performed using an amount of catalyst that corresponds to 10mol% of amine, as determined by elemental analysis. This was achieved through scaling the amount of catalyst added while maintaining the amount of the reaction mixture. 3 Results and discussion The composite organic and inorganic catalysts are successfully synthesized through grafting organosilanes on the surface of a calcined mesoporous silica material (Fig. S1). The materials are characterized before and after grafting the organosilane using nitrogen physisorption, demonstrating a type IV isotherm as expected (Figs. S2 and S4). The materials are also investigated using TGA-DSC and found to have an organic content proportional to the amount of organosilane added during the grafting procedure (Figs. S3 and S4). Since TGA analysis provides an approximate loading of organosilane, the nitrogen content and correspondingly the amount of tertiary amine on the surface were determined using elemental analysis CHN (Table S1). As expected, the grafting efficiency (actual/theoretical loading) decreases for higher theoretical loadings since the surface monolayer coverage has a maximum of approximately 1.5mmolg−1. Attempting to achieve higher loadings would produce a multi-layer of organosilanes and result in inaccessible amines [22]. The first material tested is SBA-C3-0.52, and it is found to be active for the isomerization of glucose to fructose, achieving after 24h a 7% conversion of glucose with a selectivity of 68% to fructose (Fig. 2 ), which is less than the equilibrium glucose conversion expected at this temperature that has been calculated to be ∼55% [4]. Extending the reaction time to 48h does not increase the overall conversion or selectivity. Compared to homogeneous results [7], the heterogeneous catalytic material has lower catalytic activity, but comparable selectivity. The lower catalytic activity is likely associated with the immobilization of the amine on the support. Immobilizing the catalyst on a silica support introduces complexity into the system since the heterogeneous support has surface silanols that can affect the reaction. With the low loading of SBA-C3-0.52 (i.e., 0.52mmolg−1), the exposed surface silanols can interact with the immobilized amine or glucose to decrease the rate of reaction. The effect of the silanol surface on the reaction is tested through comparing the catalytic activities of homogeneous triethylamine with and without silica. With mesoporous silica (∼100mg of bare SBA-15; comparable to amount of functionalized catalysts), the conversion is lower than without silica (Fig. S5), indicating that the silica surface inhibited the reaction. The inhibition could be caused by amine-silanol interactions, glucose-silanol interactions, or both. The experiments with homogeneous catalysts do not differentiate the potential sources of the inhibition, but indicate the presence of silanols decreases catalytic activity. Several strategies exist to limit the silanol interference with the reaction, including: (1) increasing organosilane loading, (2) hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS) capping, or (3) shortening the organosilane alkyl linker length. Specifically, increasing the organosilane loading will reduce the number of silanols since the organosilane replaces the silanols on the surface. Accordingly, catalysts with different loadings of the tertiary amine are synthesized and compared for glucose conversion. With increasing loading, the catalytic activity is observed to increase significantly with the highly loaded materials SBA-C3-1.46 achieving 25% conversion in two hours, as shown in Fig. 2. High fructose selectivity (∼70–80%) is observed in the first two hours of reaction after which selectivity decreases to ∼65% at 24h. This positive effect from increasing the loading could be attributed to reducing silanols or locally increasing the basicity of the material. With increasing loading, the number of amines in close proximity increases and could cause the local pH to change, as has been observed for sulfonic acid species on silica surfaces [23,24]. Previously, the pH was identified as important for the isomerization of glucose [8]. Therefore, alternative strategies are investigated to deconvolute the effects of silanols and surface amine density on the reaction activity and selectivity. HMDS capping selectively removes the surface silanols and replaces the silanols with a hydrophobic trimethylsilyl group. After capping the silanols of SBA-C3-0.44 with HMDS (material is labeled SBA-C3-0.44-HMDS), the material is tested for isomerization of glucose. Although HMDS capping removes surface silanols, the hydrophobic trimethylsilyl groups introduces further complexity into the system since it is observed that mixing the hydrophobic material with the aqueous reaction solution does not result in wetting of the material surface, necessitating an increase in the stirring rate. For the higher stirring rate, the conversions for SBA-C3-0.44-HMDS and SBA-C3-0.44 materials is found to be similar (Table S3), suggesting eliminating silanols with HMDS is not an effective strategy to increase catalytic activity for this system. Indeed, HMDS treatment reduces silanol content, but also introduces solvent like interactions into the system. While solvents can be used to tune catalytic activity and selectivity for some reactions [3,25], this is not the case for the isomerization of glucose to fructose. Creating a 50:50 (v:v) mixture of different miscible solvents including tetrahydrofuran (THF) and dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) reduced the catalytic activity and/or selectivity (Table S4). Since these solvents are commonly used for the potential tandem reaction of fructose dehydration to 5-hydroxymethylfurfuraldehyde [26], these data suggest alternative strategies are needed to achieve this tandem reaction in one pot. The HMDS capped materials provided important insights on solvent interactions (outer sphere effects), but did not clarify the relative importance for the isomerization of glucose of eliminating surface silanols as opposed to increasing the local pH. An alternative strategy for mitigating amine-silanol interactions is to utilize an organosilane with a methyl linker. The methyl linker was previously demonstrated for primary and secondary amines to limit the interactions of the amines with surface silanols [2,18,27]. Materials are synthesized with (N,N-diethyl)-aminomethyl triethoxysilane, producing materials with loadings of 0.52 and 0.95mmolg−1. These materials are tested in the isomerization reaction. As shown in Fig. 3 for similar loadings (SBA-C1-0.52 vs. SBA-C3-0.52), the material with the methyl linker is more active and selective than the material with the propyl linker. While the methyl linker has a clear advantage for this reaction, the observed difference could be associated with the close proximity of the amine to silicon atom influencing the basicity of the amine. Amine basicity was evaluated using density functional theory (DFT) calculations to determine the effect of the linker length on amine basicity. DFT calculations (details in SI) determined a negligible pKb difference, which suggests the linker length has minimal impact on the basicity of the two amine species. Given the similarity in basicity, these experimental results support the hypothesis that limiting amine-silanol interactions increases the catalytic activity. Interestingly, as shown in Fig. 4 , increasing the loading (SBA-C1-0.95) further improves the catalytic activity, indicating that higher densities of amines on the surface provide additional benefits. Attempts to increase the amine loading of the organosilane with the methyl linker beyond 0.95mmolg−1 did not increase the amine loading. Overall, these results demonstrate the importance of tuning the catalytic material design to increase catalytic activity, as shown in Fig. 5 . Through tuning the density and the organosilane structure, the turnover frequency can be improved significantly. While increasing the amine loading and shortening the amine tether increased the TOF, the final glucose conversion for both SBA-C3-1.46 and SBA-C1-0.95 is around 30%. We hypothesize that the basic sites are neutralized during the course of the reaction by acidic species generated as byproducts [28], which causes the reaction to stop. Indeed, the pH of the reaction solution after 5h at reaction conditions decreased from 9.1 to 6.8 (±0.2), indicating the generating of acidic species that would stop the reaction [8]. Since the reaction was performed under an air atmosphere, the acidic species could be the result of oxygen or CO2 present in the reaction mixture. Degassing the reaction solutions and then performing the reactions under nitrogen did not affect the rate of reaction since the conversion at 1h was similar regardless of whether nitrogen or air was present, as seen in Fig. 6 . However, reactions performed under a nitrogen environment had increased conversion of 36% after 5h relative to 30% conversion under air. Under nitrogen, the conversion plateaued at 36%, indicating that acidic species form regardless of gas environment. The ability to reuse the catalyst was evaluated by testing the catalyst in a series of glucose isomerization reactions. From previous experience working with organosilanes, it is known that the organosilane with the methyl linker grafts onto the silica surface in a tripodal manner [18], which potentially could increase the catalyst stability. The nature of the organosilane bonding to the surface was investigated using 29Si CP/MAS NMR for both SBA-C1-0.95 and SBA-C3-1.46, as shown in Fig. 7 . Both spectra consist of Q and T sites. Q4 (Si(OSi ≡ )4) and Q3 (Si(OSi ≡ )3OH) sites at −111 and −102ppm respectively with small shoulder at −92ppm for Q2 (Si(OSi ≡ )2(OH)2) sites are visible in both spectra. T sites that characterize the organosilane-silica surface bonding are generally observed between −50ppm to −80ppm. Many factors affect the absolute peak positions for the different T sites [29], but the general trend is an upfield shift of −10 ppm for silicon atoms with an increasing number of surface linkages. For SBA-C3-1.46, peaks at −60ppm and −68ppm peaks are observed that have been previously assigned as T2 (bipodal) and T3 (tripodal) sites respectively for aminopropyl functionalized SBA-15 [17]. For SBA-C1-0.95, a small peak at −77ppm is observed that can be attributed to a T3 (tripodal) site, which supports the hypothesis that the linker length affects the bonding of the organosilane to the silica surface. The ability to reuse the catalyst is tested for SBA-C1-0.95 and SBA-C3-1.46, which are the most active catalysts for each alkyl linker length. For the reuse experiments, the initial amounts of fresh catalyst and reaction mixture is scaled up by a factor of five to enable recovery of sufficient catalytic materials to facilitate the reuse of the catalyst, allowing determination of conversion data for the different times since each data point requires ∼100mg. After 5h of reaction time, the reaction solution is quenched, diluted with 0.3M mannitol solution and filtered using a two-piece filtration apparatus. The filtered catalyst is washed with 50mL DI water and oven-dried at 80°C overnight. The once used catalysts are labeled SBA-C1-0.95-re1 and SBA-C3-1.46-re1, respectively. After the first catalytic test, these materials are still mesoporous, as demonstrated by N2 physisorption (Fig. S9). As shown in Table S1, TGA and EA of the used catalysts indicate leaching of the amine groups. However, on reusing these catalysts for another 5h reaction, it is determined that no additional amine group leaching occurs (Fig. S10). For the reactions using SBA-C1-0.95-re1 and SBA-C3-1.46-re1, the amount of catalyst used is scaled based upon these elemental analysis results for the used catalysts to maintain an amine loading of 10mol%. For SBA-C1-0.95-re1 (0.52mmolg−1 amine loading), catalytic testing results in 18% glucose conversion with a fructose selectivity of 76%. This conversion is lower than the conversion obtained after two hours for the fresh catalysts SBA-C1-0.96 (28%) and SBA-C1-0.52 (23%), but the selectivity is similar. To determine if the initial catalyst activity is also affected, SBA-C1-0.95-re1 is used for a 1h reaction. The conversion obtained in 1h (10%) is similar to the conversion obtained for fresh SBA-C1-0.52 (11%), suggesting that the amine immobilized on the silica surface retain catalytic activity and that leaching is the predominant deactivation mechanism. This behavior is different than the deactivation for the polymers, which required addition of salts to prevent amine deactivation [14]. In the case of SBA-C3-1.46-re1 (1.04mmolg−1 amine loading), the conversion after 5h is only 3% with 62% fructose selectivity. The conversion increases to 6% with 87% fructose selectivity after 24h. Both these conversion values are half of what is observed for a fresh SBA-C3-0.85 (comparable loading to SBA-C3-1.46-re1) catalyst. This demonstrates the length of the tether not only affects the catalyst kinetics, but also affects its overall stability. After first reuse, the methyl-linker catalyst demonstrates kinetics comparable to a fresh SBA-C1 catalyst with similar tertiary amine loading. Combined, these results indicate that methyl linkers outperform propyl linker for the isomerization of glucose to fructose. Overall, a highly selective catalyst for glucose isomerization to fructose is described. The catalyst synthesis involves functionalization of a tertiary amine group to a heterogeneous and porous SBA-15 surface. This catalyst design combines the benefits of high selectivity of tertiary amines with benefits such as ease of preparation and porosity of the support SBA-15 materials. We found that surface silanols play an important role in governing the catalyst activity. Decreasing the length of the active site tether and increasing the surface concentration of the active site improve the catalyst performance significantly. As such, SBA-C1-0.95 resulted in the highest fructose yield (23%) with a high fructose selectivity (75%). On first use, some organosilane leached from the catalyst surface. However, on second use, almost no change in the organosilane leaching was observed. For the used catalyst with the methyl linker, some decrease in activity is observed, but it still maintains a high selectivity toward fructose (75%). coredata.dc:description: Glucose isomerization to fructose is an important step in upgrading biomass to higher valued products. Tertiary amines can be highly selective catalysts for this reaction. In this work, tertiary amine analogues were functionalized on a mesoporous silica support to create heterogeneous catalytic materials. Experiments with homogeneous catalysts and silica revealed that silanols reduced the catalytic activity. Through using different strategies to limit amine-silanol interactions, it is determined that tuning parameters such as amine loading and alkyl linker length of the amine tether increases the fructose yield by a factor of four. Among the catalysts tested, the one found to be the best for glucose isomerization has a high amine loading (∼0.95mmolg−1) with a methyl linker. Catalyst reuse tests demonstrated that organosilane leaching reduced amine content, but the immobilized amines with the methyl linker retained greater catalytic activity than amines with propyl linkers.
coredata.dc:title: Selectively converting glucose to fructose using immobilized tertiary amines
